str2: A primary particle; but, and, etc.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Middle - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To begin. Middle voice of archo; to commence.
To accuse, charge, prosecute. From kategoros; to be a plaintiff, i.e. To charge with some offence.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: (a) I say, speak; I mean, mention, tell, (b) I call, name, especially in the pass., (c) I tell, command.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 1st Person Plural
str2: A prolonged form of a primary heuro, which heureo is used for it in all the tenses except the present and imperfect to find.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: To pervert, corrupt, oppose, distort. From dia and strepho; to distort, i.e. misinterpret, or corrupt.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
Probably from etho; a race, i.e. A tribe; specially, a foreign one.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: To prevent, debar, hinder; with infin: from doing so and so. From the base of kolazo; to estop, i.e. Prevent.
A tax, tribute, especially on persons. From phero; a load, i.e. a tax.
Of Latin origin; Caesar, a title of the Roman emperor.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: (a) I say, speak; I mean, mention, tell, (b) I call, name, especially in the pass., (c) I tell, command.

parse: Reflexive Pronoun - Accusative Masculine 3rd Person Singular

str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
Anointed One; the Messiah, the Christ. From chrio; Anointed One, i.e. The Messiah, an epithet of Jesus.
A king, ruler, but in some passages clearly to be translated: emperor. Probably from basis; a sovereign.
